pr:sect1.name: Section 5
pr:sect1.pr:title: Purpose
pr:sect1.pr:para: This is a placeholder for any implementation profiles of GeoSciML that we need to specify for an expectation of conformance with GeoSciML

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: Data products will conform to the model defined in the identified version of GeoSciML, using the conformance requirements specified by the GeoSciML data product.
Data products will conform to the model defined in the identified version of GeoSciML, using the conformance requirements specified by the GeoSciML data product.

pr:profile.pr:name: GeoSciML WMS
pr:profile.pr:description: This profile binds the GeoSciML data products to the basic WMS profile.

pr:sect1.name: Section 6
pr:sect1.pr:title: Content
pr:sect1.pr:para: Do we need to specify layer naming approach here?

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: Data products will conform to the model defined in the identified version of GeoSciML, using the conformance requirements specified by the GeoSciML data product.
WMS_GETFEATUREINFO_FORMAT MUST support valid GML 2.1 and SHOULD support GML 3.1.1 format responses [SHANE] - Benchmark technology support

Response from GetFeatureInfo SHOULD be identical to a response from a WFS request for the same Feature. [SHANE] - I think this may be a part of the benchmarking process: This is probably a key area to put pressure on vendors, and wrappers in short term - a single data source providing WMS and WFS should share a common config and common output schema
The response time for a getMap operation for an image less than 1000 pixels by 1000 pixels SHOULD be less than 2 seconds, not including network data transfer time.
The map server MUSTbe able to deliver images up to 1000 pixels by 1000 pixels

pr:requirement.pr:name: WMS_VERSION_1_1_1
pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: capabilites MUST have a version attribute with a value of '1.1.1'. WMS 1.1.1 section 6.1 This implies that the artefact binding asks for version 1.1.1

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: Currently almost all geospatial software vendors support WMS version 1.1.1 and do not yet support the emerging 1.3 WMS version. In addition the relatively small number of Queensland Government WMS services are also utilising version 1.1.1. This requirement will be periodically reviewed and when appropriate will be amended to include susequesnt version releases over time. [MARK] - write the non-normative content.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.1
ud:example.ud:caption: Version attribute correctly states version 1.1.1

ud:example.name: Figure 4.2
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrect version of WMS

pr:requirement.pr:name: Topic Category
pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: For each MD_TopicCategoryCode found in corresponding service metadata document (obtained from the MetadataUrl URL) there MUST be a corresponding Keyword element. Ian to write paragraph on the relationship between wfs/wms capabilities document and the metadata. 14/6 - need to create separate xml metadata docs for each of the 3 layers in the service (export from the CRS). Need to make sure that the topic category in each of the layer metadata records matches the keywords/topic categories in the service metadata and the capabilites document.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: The MD_TopicCategoryCode element is a controlled list of thematic classifications provided in ISO 19115. These classifications assist in categorising like data and information resources so search applications can find resources concerning particular themes.

This requirement maps the keywords used for the layers in a service to the ISO 19115 Topic Categories. The effectivness of catalogue search functions will be limited if services do not are not categorised similarly to the underlying data layers, therefore will not be allowed under this profile.
The examples need to come from the 4 metadata docs and the capabilities doc.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.3
ud:example.ud:caption: Topic category correctly listed in the ISO19115 metadata document. The metadata document for this example can be found at URL location http://myservice.org/metadata/infrastructure.xml

ud:example.name: Figure 4.4
ud:example.ud:caption: Keyword list correctly listed in the WMS capabilities document and contains the keyword "infrastructure" as specified in the metadata document for the layer.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.5
ud:example.ud:caption: Topic category correctly listed in the ISO19115 metadata document.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.6
ud:example.ud:caption: Keyword list incorrectly listed in the WMS capabilities document as it does not contain the keyword "infrastructure" as specified in the metadata document for the layer.

pr:normative-content.pr:comment: [SHANE] - Not sure about the need for this given the content below

pr:requirement.pr:name: Contact Person
pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: need to make sure that the correct example matches queensland goverment busines rules [MARK] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. sdiWMS0001 - sdiWMS0001_2service MUST contain exactly one ContactPersonPrimary element.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: This is to identify the name of the person currently acting in the role defined in requirement sdiWMS0003 sdiWMS0001. Each service offering MUST contain reference to a designated position, responsible for the custodianship and management of the service. It is also desirable that this role is also reflected in the position description of the described position

ud:example.name: Figure 4.7

ContactAddress.Address: NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Code 933

ud:example.ud:caption: Correct example

ud:example.name: Figure 4.8

ContactAddress.Address: NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Code 933

ud:example.ud:caption: Icorrect example

pr:requirement.pr:name: CONTACT_ORGANISATION_REQUIRED
pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [MARK] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. contact-organisation MUST contain ContactPersonPrimary or ContactPosition

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: This is to identify the Queensland Government position responsible for the custodianship and management of the service. The individual filling this role MUST have detailed content (but no necessarily technical) knowledge of the service. It is also desirable that this role is also reflected in the position description of the described position.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.9
ud:example.ud:caption: Senior Project Officer - Service Implementation Senior Scientist - Water Resources

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [MARK] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. contact-organisation MUST contain ContactFacsimileTelephone or ContactElectronicMailAddress

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: This describes the contact telephone numbers of the position responsible for the sercive, as described in R0003sdiWMS0000.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: service MUST contain exactly one Abstract element.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: The Abstract is a brief narrative summary of the content of the service. Careful consideration should be given when preparing an Abstract as it is an important element for the identification and discovery of a service. Other material to be conveyed in this element may include a description of the purpose for which the service was created, and a textual description of the spatial extent of the data contained in the service. Generally, the Abstract should describe the contents of the service for a non-expert user, in plain language. It should be more than a repeat of the title. While the Abstract element is optional in the WMS 1.1.1. specficiation (see section 7.1.4.5.3), this profile stipulates that an abstract is REQUIRED.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.11

highlight.Abstract: WMT Map Server maintained by Acme Corporation. Contact: webmaster@wmt.acme.com. High-quality maps showing roadrunner nests and possible ambush locations.

ud:example.ud:caption: A compliant WMS Service contains an abstract element.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.12
ud:example.ud:caption: An non compliant WMS Service that does not contain an abstract element.

pr:requirement.pr:name: CURRENCY
pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. invocable-layer MUST contain exactly one currency keyword containing a term from the data currency controlled vocabulary [fix xpath]] URN of vocabulary (example below) needs to be a published artefact resolvable with sdi architecture. ebRIM classification have been defined.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: A WMS service can depict information from a wide range of data sources and of varying temporal content. To aid catalogue searching for services depicting current or historical or predicted data content, a keyword is used to give a general indication of the currency of the data depicted within a service. Because keywords are unqualified and multi-valued, each instance must be a fully qualified (unambiguous) URN. The classification scheme used is a controlled vocabulary for "Data Currency" (whose initial content is adopted from the Australian marine SDI community, and includes the keywords "Current", "Historical", "Predicted" and "Unknown".)

ud:example.name: Figure 4.13
ud:example.ud:caption: Correct usage

ud:example.name: Figure 4.14
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrect usage.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: Mark to do invocable-layer MUST contain exactly one topic keyword containing a term from the sdi registry topic [get ref] controlled vocabulary URN of vocabulary (example below) needs to be a published artefact resolvable with sdi architecture. Isn't this the same as XXXXX555 - no, refers to referencing possibly multiple thesauri e.g. SSQ Govt Categories (Land and Resources, Business and Industry etc), or the Australian Mining Handbook (what ever it's called), ANZLIC, QKey. Jacek to meet with Sam on Monday. Need to determine appropriate custodian for each of the thesauri.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: Meaningful and representitive keywords are required to ensure simple and consisitant searching for related information. Both the spelling and keywords used should be from one of the keyword lists endorsed by the custodian of keyword lists for Queensland Government. At least one keyword is required to assist in finding required services.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [MICAH] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. invocable-layer SHOULD contain minimum and maximum display scales supported for each layer by populating the scale-hint element. See table 7 for inheritance by parent from child.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: The inclusion of maximum (max) and minimum (min) scale hints assist in delivering reliable performance of services and aides in limiting misuse of data by restricting the viewable scales to match the data accuracy. Each layer should have a "max" and "min" scale hint. In some cases, it may be acceptable to not include a scale hint such as a map service that provides static images of non-georeferenced data, or a service that provides sparsely populated data that is captured with sufficient accuracy e.g. a statewide GPS point dataset of species locations that contains minimal data. In this case the data is accurate at the property scale and is geographically sparse enough not to adversly effect rendering performance.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. [JACEK] add a paragraph on the technical component, ie linking from the Capabilities document to the Metadata document. invocable-layer MUST contain exactly one metadata-url keyword that references a sdi standard dataset metadata profile XML document. This will be an ISO 19139 conformant implementation of the ISO 19115 metadata standard referred to by the keyword "TC211". Some services within the QG may already use FGDC. This requirement may need to be deleted.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: Each layer that maybe depicted in a web map service should be described in the metadata document. A web map service must use one or more MetadataURL elements to offer detailed, standardized metadata about the data corresponding to a particular layer. The 'type' attribute indicates the standard to which the metadata complies. Two 'type' attribute values are defined by the International Standard: the value 'TC211' refers the ISO 19115 metadata standard . The target is actually ANZLIC's ISO 19139 conformant implementation profile, which should be separately validated as part of the metadata publishing regime. The enclosed <Format> element indicates the file format MIME type of the metadata record. This must be text/xml, indicating an XML document. MetadataURL elements are not inherited by a parent Layers. Examples in the Infolink capabilities file reflect this non-inheritance.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.15
ud:example.ud:caption: Correctly formatted reference to a metadata document.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.16
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrectly formatted reference to a metadata document.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [SHANE] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. Jacek to investigate metadata document structure and find appropriate conformance target for this requirement. layer-currency-end-date MUST be present.
Both layer-currency-start-date and layer-currency-end-date MUST use YYYY-MM-DD date format.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: The layer currency start date is the earliest date at which the phenomena in the layer actually occurred. The layer currency end date is the latest date at which the phenomena in the layer actually occurred. This is not necessarily the date on which a record was entered into a database. This element records the age of the data in the layer itself. It is possible that data may be recorded many years after an event eg an earthquake or a flood. It is the date that the event itself occurred which is required in this element. The date of conversion of data from one form to another form or one database to another, or the date of conversion of the dataset to a specific format or to a specific system should not be recorded. The format for the layer-currency-start-date and layer-currency-end-date MUST use the YYYY-MM-DD date format
relax asserton to allow timestamps. SHOULD include timezone

ud:example.name: Figure 4.17
ud:example.ud:caption: Correctly formatted currency start and end dates.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.18
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrectly formatted currency end date

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [SHANE] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. exception MUST support XML and in_image format exceptions This requires mark to do more technology benchmarking. Probably what the word means...

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: The exception tag provides information about the exception formats a client can ask for when making requests. Examples of clients in this case may refer to custom built desktop applications or browser based applications. The decision to support xml as well as inimage was made to provide the maximum flexibility for application developers. The inimage option will provide users with an exception message embedded in an image - this is predominately useful to provide a visual message of the unavailabiliy of a service, or to relate other relevant error messages. The XML format provides functionality for developers to trap errors as they occur and implement an appropriate solution to deal with the error or exception.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.19
ud:example.ud:caption: Correct example of defining the available exception formats in a service.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.20
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrect example of defining the available exception formats in a service.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. Services MUST be provided using a Spatial Reference System for latitude and longitude coordinates in decimal degrees on the Geocentric Datum of Australia (GDA94). layer

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: Services can be offered in a range of different spatial reference systems. Generally the service SRS is defined in the parent layer but an SRS can be defined on a leaf layer as well. Any leaf layer SRS is added to the defined parent layer SRS and is available in all those stated SRS. Users should be aware that a service may not be displayed in a client viewer if the viewer SRS is not specified in the service capabilities file.
A full list of EPSG codes can be found in a Microsoft Access .mdb file at http://www.epsg.org/

ud:example.name: Figure 4.21
ud:example.ud:caption: Correct format of service SRS definition.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.22
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrect format of service SRS definition.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [MICAH] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. getmap must include PNG (image/png). This should support transparency and image compression.

[JACEK] to move this requirement to an ancestor profile and document it service must contain one or more keywords containing the URN of the sdi profile it supports. The URNs of profiles are as defined here. Stick profiles into CRS.
[MICAH] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. invocable-layer SHOULDadvertise it's opacity. Technology benchmark this too!

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: Reference table 7 : Inheritance of layer table properties, section 7.1.4.7, note child properties when defined over-ride those defined properties of the parent

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. layer MUSTspecify the layer is "subsettable" (nosubsets = "0" if declared) (WMS 1.1.1 section 7.1.4.6.4). Need to check with Rob if we really want this requirement apply to all WMS services.

[IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. layer MUSTspecify the layer is not "fixedWidth" or "fixedHeight" (WMS 1.1.1 section 7.1.4.6.4). Need to check with Rob if we really want this requirement apply to all WMS services.

[MARK] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. A capabilites SHOULD NOT contain more than 100 layers. May need to limit to deal with harvesting limitations in CRS or other client ability to cope with large numbers.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: When a map service is created, consideration should be given to the service content, and the intented purpose of the service, with a view to maximising usability in client applications. This requirement aims to balance the complexity of presenting numerous data layers in one service and still provide some logical client application usability and interaction with the service. In certain situations, particularly for organisations wanting to offer all their custodial information as layers in a single service, it may be necessary to exceed this limit.
Consideration should be also given to organising service layers into logical groupings to aid interaction using client viewers and reduce complexity.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.23
ud:example.ud:caption: Correct format of grouping service layers for ease of use.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.24
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrect format of grouping service layers for ease of use.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: The relevant OGC service capabilities metadata is populated with service custodian identifier. Different versions and type of OGC Web Services have different schemas, however OGC has a proposed OWS_Common framework to standardise this aspect in newer versions (WFS 1.1, WMS 1.3?). [SHANE] - Need to benchmark wms/wfs versions and make a decision.

The supported Spatial Reference System for all data will include GDA94/Plate Carree (Orthogeographic) projection (known as EPSG:4283 in WMS 1.1.1 (Note that WMS 1.3 changed the axis-order (lat/long) for this, and is not widely adopted). [SHANE] - [SRS handling for WFS/GML in target environment should be benchmarked]

[IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct or incorrect usage. Currency of data set (NB ISO19115 does not seem to provide a slot for this) MUST be described using keyword from (CRS data currency keywords vocabulary identifier - ISO19115 provides these?) [The user will need to know whether the data is the most recent available or a historical snapshot or a prediction - this is not currently part of the FGDC metadata /CRS design, but it will need to be eventually, so we need to add it to service profiles so the info will be available when needed. there is a bigger general issue that the sdi architecture requires the ability to publish vocabularies and then reference them.]

pr:sect1.name: Section 7
pr:sect1.pr:title: Content
pr:sect1.pr:para: Do we need to specify layer naming approach here?

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: LAYER MUST provide 1:1million scale Lithostratigraphic Unit in a Layer called urn:somethingTimwilFillin

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: Data products will conform to the model defined in the identified version of GeoSciML, using the conformance requirements specified by the GeoSciML data product.
WMS_GETFEATUREINFO_FORMAT MUST support valid GML 2.1 and SHOULD support GML 3.1.1 format responses [SHANE] - Benchmark technology support

Response from GetFeatureInfo SHOULD be identical to a response from a WFS request for the same Feature. [SHANE] - I think this may be a part of the benchmarking process: This is probably a key area to put pressure on vendors, and wrappers in short term - a single data source providing WMS and WFS should share a common config and common output schema
The response time for a getMap operation for an image less than 1000 pixels by 1000 pixels SHOULD be less than 2 seconds, not including network data transfer time.
The map server MUSTbe able to deliver images up to 1000 pixels by 1000 pixels

pr:requirement.pr:name: WMS_VERSION_1_1_1
pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: capabilites MUST have a version attribute with a value of '1.1.1'. WMS 1.1.1 section 6.1 This implies that the artefact binding asks for version 1.1.1

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: Currently almost all geospatial software vendors support WMS version 1.1.1 and do not yet support the emerging 1.3 WMS version. In addition the relatively small number of Queensland Government WMS services are also utilising version 1.1.1. This requirement will be periodically reviewed and when appropriate will be amended to include susequesnt version releases over time. [MARK] - write the non-normative content.

pr:requirement.pr:name: Topic Category
pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: For each MD_TopicCategoryCode found in corresponding service metadata document (obtained from the MetadataUrl URL) there MUST be a corresponding Keyword element. Ian to write paragraph on the relationship between wfs/wms capabilities document and the metadata. 14/6 - need to create separate xml metadata docs for each of the 3 layers in the service (export from the CRS). Need to make sure that the topic category in each of the layer metadata records matches the keywords/topic categories in the service metadata and the capabilites document.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: The MD_TopicCategoryCode element is a controlled list of thematic classifications provided in ISO 19115. These classifications assist in categorising like data and information resources so search applications can find resources concerning particular themes.

This requirement maps the keywords used for the layers in a service to the ISO 19115 Topic Categories. The effectivness of catalogue search functions will be limited if services do not are not categorised similarly to the underlying data layers, therefore will not be allowed under this profile.
The examples need to come from the 4 metadata docs and the capabilities doc.

pr:requirement.pr:name: CONTACT_ORGANISATION_REQUIRED
pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [MARK] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. contact-organisation MUST contain ContactPersonPrimary or ContactPosition

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: This is to identify the Queensland Government position responsible for the custodianship and management of the service. The individual filling this role MUST have detailed content (but no necessarily technical) knowledge of the service. It is also desirable that this role is also reflected in the position description of the described position.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.9
ud:example.ud:caption: Senior Project Officer - Service Implementation Senior Scientist - Water Resources

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [MARK] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. contact-organisation MUST contain ContactFacsimileTelephone or ContactElectronicMailAddress

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: This describes the contact telephone numbers of the position responsible for the sercive, as described in R0003sdiWMS0000.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: service MUST contain exactly one Abstract element.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: The Abstract is a brief narrative summary of the content of the service. Careful consideration should be given when preparing an Abstract as it is an important element for the identification and discovery of a service. Other material to be conveyed in this element may include a description of the purpose for which the service was created, and a textual description of the spatial extent of the data contained in the service. Generally, the Abstract should describe the contents of the service for a non-expert user, in plain language. It should be more than a repeat of the title. While the Abstract element is optional in the WMS 1.1.1. specficiation (see section 7.1.4.5.3), this profile stipulates that an abstract is REQUIRED.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.11

highlight.Abstract: WMT Map Server maintained by Acme Corporation. Contact: webmaster@wmt.acme.com. High-quality maps showing roadrunner nests and possible ambush locations.

ud:example.ud:caption: A compliant WMS Service contains an abstract element.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.12
ud:example.ud:caption: An non compliant WMS Service that does not contain an abstract element.

pr:requirement.pr:name: CURRENCY
pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. invocable-layer MUST contain exactly one currency keyword containing a term from the data currency controlled vocabulary [fix xpath]] URN of vocabulary (example below) needs to be a published artefact resolvable with sdi architecture. ebRIM classification have been defined.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: A WMS service can depict information from a wide range of data sources and of varying temporal content. To aid catalogue searching for services depicting current or historical or predicted data content, a keyword is used to give a general indication of the currency of the data depicted within a service. Because keywords are unqualified and multi-valued, each instance must be a fully qualified (unambiguous) URN. The classification scheme used is a controlled vocabulary for "Data Currency" (whose initial content is adopted from the Australian marine SDI community, and includes the keywords "Current", "Historical", "Predicted" and "Unknown".)

ud:example.name: Figure 4.13
ud:example.ud:caption: Correct usage

ud:example.name: Figure 4.14
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrect usage.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: Mark to do invocable-layer MUST contain exactly one topic keyword containing a term from the sdi registry topic [get ref] controlled vocabulary URN of vocabulary (example below) needs to be a published artefact resolvable with sdi architecture. Isn't this the same as XXXXX555 - no, refers to referencing possibly multiple thesauri e.g. SSQ Govt Categories (Land and Resources, Business and Industry etc), or the Australian Mining Handbook (what ever it's called), ANZLIC, QKey. Jacek to meet with Sam on Monday. Need to determine appropriate custodian for each of the thesauri.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: Meaningful and representitive keywords are required to ensure simple and consisitant searching for related information. Both the spelling and keywords used should be from one of the keyword lists endorsed by the custodian of keyword lists for Queensland Government. At least one keyword is required to assist in finding required services.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [MICAH] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. invocable-layer SHOULD contain minimum and maximum display scales supported for each layer by populating the scale-hint element. See table 7 for inheritance by parent from child.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: The inclusion of maximum (max) and minimum (min) scale hints assist in delivering reliable performance of services and aides in limiting misuse of data by restricting the viewable scales to match the data accuracy. Each layer should have a "max" and "min" scale hint. In some cases, it may be acceptable to not include a scale hint such as a map service that provides static images of non-georeferenced data, or a service that provides sparsely populated data that is captured with sufficient accuracy e.g. a statewide GPS point dataset of species locations that contains minimal data. In this case the data is accurate at the property scale and is geographically sparse enough not to adversly effect rendering performance.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. [JACEK] add a paragraph on the technical component, ie linking from the Capabilities document to the Metadata document. invocable-layer MUST contain exactly one metadata-url keyword that references a sdi standard dataset metadata profile XML document. This will be an ISO 19139 conformant implementation of the ISO 19115 metadata standard referred to by the keyword "TC211". Some services within the QG may already use FGDC. This requirement may need to be deleted.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: Each layer that maybe depicted in a web map service should be described in the metadata document. A web map service must use one or more MetadataURL elements to offer detailed, standardized metadata about the data corresponding to a particular layer. The 'type' attribute indicates the standard to which the metadata complies. Two 'type' attribute values are defined by the International Standard: the value 'TC211' refers the ISO 19115 metadata standard . The target is actually ANZLIC's ISO 19139 conformant implementation profile, which should be separately validated as part of the metadata publishing regime. The enclosed <Format> element indicates the file format MIME type of the metadata record. This must be text/xml, indicating an XML document. MetadataURL elements are not inherited by a parent Layers. Examples in the Infolink capabilities file reflect this non-inheritance.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.15
ud:example.ud:caption: Correctly formatted reference to a metadata document.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.16
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrectly formatted reference to a metadata document.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [SHANE] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. Jacek to investigate metadata document structure and find appropriate conformance target for this requirement. layer-currency-end-date MUST be present.
Both layer-currency-start-date and layer-currency-end-date MUST use YYYY-MM-DD date format.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: The layer currency start date is the earliest date at which the phenomena in the layer actually occurred. The layer currency end date is the latest date at which the phenomena in the layer actually occurred. This is not necessarily the date on which a record was entered into a database. This element records the age of the data in the layer itself. It is possible that data may be recorded many years after an event eg an earthquake or a flood. It is the date that the event itself occurred which is required in this element. The date of conversion of data from one form to another form or one database to another, or the date of conversion of the dataset to a specific format or to a specific system should not be recorded. The format for the layer-currency-start-date and layer-currency-end-date MUST use the YYYY-MM-DD date format
relax asserton to allow timestamps. SHOULD include timezone

ud:example.name: Figure 4.17
ud:example.ud:caption: Correctly formatted currency start and end dates.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.18
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrectly formatted currency end date

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [SHANE] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. exception MUST support XML and in_image format exceptions This requires mark to do more technology benchmarking. Probably what the word means...

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: The exception tag provides information about the exception formats a client can ask for when making requests. Examples of clients in this case may refer to custom built desktop applications or browser based applications. The decision to support xml as well as inimage was made to provide the maximum flexibility for application developers. The inimage option will provide users with an exception message embedded in an image - this is predominately useful to provide a visual message of the unavailabiliy of a service, or to relate other relevant error messages. The XML format provides functionality for developers to trap errors as they occur and implement an appropriate solution to deal with the error or exception.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.19
ud:example.ud:caption: Correct example of defining the available exception formats in a service.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.20
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrect example of defining the available exception formats in a service.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. Services MUST be provided using a Spatial Reference System for latitude and longitude coordinates in decimal degrees on the Geocentric Datum of Australia (GDA94). layer

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: Services can be offered in a range of different spatial reference systems. Generally the service SRS is defined in the parent layer but an SRS can be defined on a leaf layer as well. Any leaf layer SRS is added to the defined parent layer SRS and is available in all those stated SRS. Users should be aware that a service may not be displayed in a client viewer if the viewer SRS is not specified in the service capabilities file.
A full list of EPSG codes can be found in a Microsoft Access .mdb file at http://www.epsg.org/

ud:example.name: Figure 4.21
ud:example.ud:caption: Correct format of service SRS definition.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.22
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrect format of service SRS definition.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [MICAH] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. getmap must include PNG (image/png). This should support transparency and image compression.

[JACEK] to move this requirement to an ancestor profile and document it service must contain one or more keywords containing the URN of the sdi profile it supports. The URNs of profiles are as defined here. Stick profiles into CRS.
[MICAH] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. invocable-layer SHOULDadvertise it's opacity. Technology benchmark this too!

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: Reference table 7 : Inheritance of layer table properties, section 7.1.4.7, note child properties when defined over-ride those defined properties of the parent

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: [IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. layer MUSTspecify the layer is "subsettable" (nosubsets = "0" if declared) (WMS 1.1.1 section 7.1.4.6.4). Need to check with Rob if we really want this requirement apply to all WMS services.

[IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. layer MUSTspecify the layer is not "fixedWidth" or "fixedHeight" (WMS 1.1.1 section 7.1.4.6.4). Need to check with Rob if we really want this requirement apply to all WMS services.

[MARK] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct and incorrect usage. A capabilites SHOULD NOT contain more than 100 layers. May need to limit to deal with harvesting limitations in CRS or other client ability to cope with large numbers.

pr:non-normative-content.pr:para: When a map service is created, consideration should be given to the service content, and the intented purpose of the service, with a view to maximising usability in client applications. This requirement aims to balance the complexity of presenting numerous data layers in one service and still provide some logical client application usability and interaction with the service. In certain situations, particularly for organisations wanting to offer all their custodial information as layers in a single service, it may be necessary to exceed this limit.
Consideration should be also given to organising service layers into logical groupings to aid interaction using client viewers and reduce complexity.

ud:example.ud:caption: Correct format of grouping service layers for ease of use.

ud:example.name: Figure 4.24
ud:example.ud:caption: Incorrect format of grouping service layers for ease of use.

pr:requirement.pr:normative-content: The relevant OGC service capabilities metadata is populated with service custodian identifier. Different versions and type of OGC Web Services have different schemas, however OGC has a proposed OWS_Common framework to standardise this aspect in newer versions (WFS 1.1, WMS 1.3?). [SHANE] - Need to benchmark wms/wfs versions and make a decision.

The supported Spatial Reference System for all data will include GDA94/Plate Carree (Orthogeographic) projection (known as EPSG:4283 in WMS 1.1.1 (Note that WMS 1.3 changed the axis-order (lat/long) for this, and is not widely adopted). [SHANE] - [SRS handling for WFS/GML in target environment should be benchmarked]

[IAN] - write the non-normative content for this requirement and provide examples of correct or incorrect usage. Currency of data set (NB ISO19115 does not seem to provide a slot for this) MUST be described using keyword from (CRS data currency keywords vocabulary identifier - ISO19115 provides these?) [The user will need to know whether the data is the most recent available or a historical snapshot or a prediction - this is not currently part of the FGDC metadata /CRS design, but it will need to be eventually, so we need to add it to service profiles so the info will be available when needed. there is a bigger general issue that the sdi architecture requires the ability to publish vocabularies and then reference them.]
